comment.author: 26492170@N02
comment._content: I live just down the road from Bandon in Donoughmore, Co. Cork. Amazing photo of a great town. The gateway to West Cork.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Streetview

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Bank of Ireland at left is from 1879.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Bandon apparently did not have electric lighting until after 1919: Letter concerned with supplying the Town of Bandon with electric lighting. Dated 20 June 1919, from Joseph Brenan, Miller and Corn Merchant, Cool Fadda Mills addressed to John Coughlan Esquire, Clerk Town Commissioners of Bandon

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Brilliant, I have a 4 year old niece who has a PHD in the same profession.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Obligatory Streetview. [EDIT - 11 minutes after Niall. My refresh button must be banjaxed :) ]

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The NIAH says most of these buildings are from 1800-1840, up to 1860. The bank is relatively recent!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Banjaxed - that will keep the foreign viewers thinking.

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content: So many ladies in big wonderful dinnerplate hats, and as you said, Carol, the ones who aren't are wearing hooded cloaks. I'm used to seeing one or two women in a photo, but there's a flock and a half here.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Interesting, Niall. I had thought that BAN... at extreme right would turn out to be a Bank of Ireland. Maybe another "make" of bank, or the start of BANDON something or other...

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Given the "great minds" rule, Niall's streetview is almost certainly spot-on. But it does beg a question: Was South Main Street "re-numbered" at some point? (I wonder because Tanners on the left are listed on the 1901 census at #48, but the equivalent building today is numbered #16. And Starkey's on the right are listed on census at #16. But the equivalent building today is number #48).

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Have you tried ticumina?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
I don't think Dr Douglas Hyde would have approved. In a lecture to the National Literacy Society on January 16 1894, it is reported (in Freeman's the following day) that
it seemed to him that the Irishmen of the present day should proceed immediately to de-Anglicise themselves. There were four things which he had singled out [1. gaelic literature 2. Irish names ] The third was a plea for their ancient music, and a protest against allowing the German band and the barrel-organ assume the place of the ancient Irish instrument, the bagpipes. [4 home-spun frieze and tweed]
I wonder what he would have made of Irishwomen using Cockney rhyming slang.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Nothing Changes! Proposal, that the local government board be requested to hold a sworn inquiry into the present financial position and workings of the town commissioners (5 November 1900, p. 30) From www.corkarchives.ie/media/TC-BNweb.pdf and Letter of accusation from [F] Donavan regarding the removal of bricks by a town commissioner from the Gas Works. Let the public see you are determined to bring Mr Wm Crowley and anyone else implicated in this crime to a sense of their duty, the public eye is watching you (3 December 1900, pp. 36 - 37)

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Census 'house numbers' had no relationship to actual number on house.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
The building face-on at the far end of the street, over the bridge, is now The Bridge Bar, 1 Oliver Plunkett street. I can't find a date for it at the DIA or NIAH, but it looks to me as if this building was not there in 1901 when the OSI 25" was surveyed, the corner entrance looks to be different.

So, I think this photo is after 1901, and if anyone can find a date for that building...

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Not always in my experience. We've seen plenty of cases where more diligent enumerators tracked the actual house numbers. (Rather than just counting doors as they walked down the street as may have been the case here.) I've seen more diligence especially on the house/building returns. Again, perhaps not in this case for one reason or another.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: This post office is from 1907, but sadly is just out of sight in this photo.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] My only quibble about a date too much later than 1901, Niall, is the bread advertisement, "Triticumina" Bread as supplied to Her Majesty the Queen. Queen Victoria died in January 1901. The lettering doesn't look old or faded, even if it wasn't changed to reflect His Majesty the King, if this photo was taken after 1901...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In the 1901 census, Michael Mohy, Postmaster, is right next to Starkey. On the OS 25" map, the P.O is marked on the right of Main Street. So, I think the building marked BAN at right is Bandon Post Office, before the 1907 move to the new building.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In this one from the nli archive, there are massive telephone poles right along the street! By 1911, Bandon Post Office had acquired a Lineman.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: O'Riordan is interesting - no O'Riordans in 1901 census. In 1911, Kathleen O'Riordan is nearby, sister-in-law of Simon Farrell, Tobacconist Stationer.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In 1901, James Magahy, Organ Builder, was living on South Main Street. Coincidence?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: "Prespitorian" William H. Birrell, also of South Main Street, Bandon was a Piano and Organ Tuner... 23 people listed as Organ Grinders in 1901 census, nobody in Cork.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: The Jeffers family are also associated with the sale of musical instruments on South Main Street. (But I think they were still grocers at this time, and unless it was used for promotional purposes, a bit too posh for organ grinding.) In any event it seems that the organ-grinder has left his Joanna and Jinny outside while popping in to the post-office..

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Ooh. There appears to be a series of letters from the younger of the two Starkey sisters (or perhaps her mother/relation of same name) hiding somewhere in Library Towers. Carol, could I trade my input to the "Great Shake-ee Mystery" for a look? (Or perhaps I'll cash-in my chips at the end of the night).

comment.author: 99646216@N00
comment._content: The women in hooded cloaks are intriguing - it seems to be a sunny day (boy squinting, other women in shirt-sleeves), but there they are, all bundled up. I'm always on the look-out for time-travellers in these photos... hmmmm...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Bandon Banjaxed Cloak Loiterers Limerick An old organ-grinder in Bandon His handle he had a firm hand on. Some folks in cloaks Almost had strokes - Ye who enter here, all hope abandon!

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Wild applause.
 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hockadilly] My theory is they're vampires, because they can't stand the sun's rays.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/la_belle_province] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hockadilly] Twas simply the fashion. Even on hotter days Irish women in mid/late 19th and early 20th century were seen in shawls, cloaks, hoods and the like. Sher didn't we see an example the other day? (Granted Mrs. Edmondson/Croker was American, but the fashion persisted til the 1920s at least).

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Excellent

comment.author: 77603809@N02
comment._content:
One wonders if the hoods and cloaks were meant in some measure to protect the wearer's hair from dust, and their clothing from that and other detritus from the animal-traveled streets of the day..
.
